intro: Pseudolycopodiella brevipedunculata, commonly known as the small-branch clubmoss, is a small, evergreen fern-like plant belonging to the family Lycopodiaceae. It is characterized by its compact, low-growing habit and its clusters of tiny, scale-like leaves. The plant produces spore-bearing structures called strobili, which are clustered at the tips of its short, branching stems. It thrives in moist, shaded environments, typically found in temperate regions. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists studying ancient plant lineages.
